title: Fish Plate

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of terracotta, red-figure.

artist_display:
Attributed to the Dotted Stripe Painter
Greek; Campania, Italy
description: Decorated tableware enlivened festive meals. This red-figured plate was used, as its decoration suggests, for serving seafood, a staple of the Mediterranean diet. Tasty juices pooled in the central concavity, which may also have contained sauces.
credit_line: Gift of Cornelius Adrian Comstock Vermeule
publication_history:
Hesperia Art Bulletin no. XLVII. Sale cat. (Philadelphia: Hesperia Arts Auction, 1969) p. 1, no. A2 (ill.). 

The Art Center at Hargate, The Classical Shape: Decorated Pottery of the Ancient World (Concord, NH: Saint Paul’s School, 1984). Exhib. Cat. no 31, ill.

Ian McPhee & A.D. Trendall, Greek Red-Figured Fish-Plates (Basel: Vereinigung d. Freunde Antiker Kunst, 1987), p. 74 (Campanian IIA, no. 62).

J. Padgett, E. Vermeule, et al., Vase-Painting in Italy (Boston: Museum of Fine Arts, 1993), pp. 167-168, no. 86 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Museum of Fine Arts Boston, from 1970 until at least 1993.

The Art Center at Hargate, The Classical Shape: Decorated Pottery of the Ancient World, 1984.

Art Institute of Chicago, Ancient Art Galleries, Gallery 155, April 20, 1994 - February 6, 2012.

Art Institute of Chicago, Of Gods and Glamour: The Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine Art, Gallery 151, November 11, 2012 - October 9, 2012.
provenance_text: Hesperia Art, Philadelphia, sold to Cornelius Clarkson Vermeule III, Boston, by 1968; on loan to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston from August 1968 - March 1997 [Padgett, Vermeule, et al., 1993, 167-168; and according to correspondence with the Museum of Fine Arts Boston dated August 25, 2023, copy in curatorial object file]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.
department_title: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
category_titles: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
